Client Selection and Bandwidth Allocation for Federated Learning: An Online Optimization Perspective

Yun Ji1, Zhoubin Kou1, Xiaoxiong Zhong1,2, Hangfan Li1, Fan Yang1, and Sheng Zhang1,* 1Graduate School in Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen, 518055, China 2Peng Cheng Laboratory, Shenzhen 518000, P.R. China *Corresponding author: Sheng Zhang, email: zhangsh@sz.tsinghua.edu.cn
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) can train a global model from clients’ local data set, which can make full use of the computing resources of clients and performs more extensive and efficient machine learning on clients with protecting user information requirements. Many existing works have focused on optimizing FL accuracy within the resource constrained in each individual round, however there are few works comprehensively consider the optimization for latency, accuracy and energy consumption over all rounds in wireless federated learning. Inspired by this, in this paper, we investigate FL in wireless network where client selection and bandwidth allocation are two crucial factors which significantly affect the latency, accuracy and energy consumption of clients. We formulate the optimization problem as a mixed-integer problem, which is to minimize the cost of time and accuracy within the long-term energy constrained over all rounds. To address this optimization, we propose the Per-round Energy Drift Plus Cost (PEDPC) algorithm in an online perspective, and the performance of the PEDPC algorithm is verified in simulation results in terms of latency, accuracy and energy consumption in IID and NON-IID dat distributions.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, client selection, bandwidth allocation, wireless network.

I Introduction

With the exponential growth of smart devices, a huge amount of data has generated each day, which inspires the application of machine learning(ML), such as predicting the traffic for autonomous vehicles, analyzing the health condition of patients [1] and detecting the status of smart home [2]. Federated learning(FL) is one of the most popular directions of distribute ML. Unlike the traditional ML, FL doesn’t centralize distributed data in clients, rather the learning process is distributed in clients using their own data, which protects the user privacy to a large extent [3]. Specifically, FL process can be described below:1): At the beginning of one round, a set of clients are selected by cloud server, then the server distributes global model to these clients; 2): After receiving the global model, the clients perform local training on their own local dataset and transmit the updated model to the cloud server; 3) The cloud server aggregate the transmitted models and update global model.

In wireless network, optimizing FL faces many challenges. On the one hand, the heterogeneous of FL, the computing power of clients varies, which incurs that some stragglers will tremendously prolong the latency of each round. On the other hand, the resource limit, the total bandwidth of all clients are finite in OFDM, which incurs that some clients in a bad channel condition maybe lost data packages while communicating with the server and even become a straggler. Besides, the energy limit, each client has an energy constraint for learning and transmission over all rounds, which incurs that not every client can be selected in each round, and the selection scheme of current round will affect the future selection. Thus optimizing FL is a long-term problem, and it’s difficult to solve. Many existing works mainly consider optimizing the FL accuracy within a resource limit in each individual round, however the latency and energy consumption are as important as the accuracy in a real-world federated learning, so how to achieve the appropriate tradeoff between these targets is quite important. On the other hand, many existing works only consider the optimal problem in each individual round omitting the dependence of different rounds [4-6], Particularly, early effort on long-term FL optimization is presented in [7]. The author maximizes the linear function which is empirically proportional to the accuracy within the energy limit, but it does not consider the time latency of FL.

In this paper, we jointly optimize the client selection and bandwidth allocation to minimize the latency plus negative accuracy (denoted as cost function in part II function within the long-term energy limit. The main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    Due to the complexity of the long-term problem, we propose a Lyapunov-based algorithm called PEDPC to translate the origin offline problem to a per-round problem. We prove that the PEDPC algorithm can achieve a tradeoff between cost and energy consumption.

  • •

    To solve the mixed-integer problem we optimize client selection and bandwidth allocation iteratively, and propose an algorithm called Increasing Time-Maximum Client Selection(ITMCS) to select clients according to the ascend order of predicted latency of all clients.

  • •

    We consider the high heterogeneity of client ability, data distribution and data size in the experiments, and the performance of our algorithms is verified by extensive simulations.

II-D Problem Formulation

A joint problem of client selection and bandwidth allocation is considered in this section, which minimizes the cost function over rounds while satisfying energy budget constraints of each client. The problem is formulated as follows:

P1:minx​(0),b​(0),…,x​(R−1),b​(R−1)⁡1R​∑r=0R−1y0​(x​(r),b​(r)):P1subscript𝑥0𝑏0…𝑥𝑅1𝑏𝑅11𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟0𝑅1subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟\displaystyle\textbf{P1}:~{}\min_{x(0),b(0),...,x(R-1),b(R-1)}\frac{1}{R}\sum\limits_{r=0}^{R-1}{{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r))} (11)

where constraint (12) guarantees that the energy consumption of selected client k𝑘k over R𝑅R rounds does not exceed the energy budget Hksubscript𝐻𝑘{{H}_{k}}. Constraint (13) ensures that the bandwidth of every client is at least bminsubscript𝑏{{b}_{\min}}. Constraint (14) indicates that the sum of all allocated bandwidth equals to B𝐵B. Constraint (15) defines that each client is selected or not in round r𝑟r.

To solve P1, we have to know full information (e.g., channel gain) about the future R𝑅R rounds in advance, but it’s almost impossible in practical situation. Thus, we need to translate P1 into an online problem which can be solved without knowing any prior knowledge of future rounds. First we divided R𝑅R rounds into F𝐹F frames, and each frame includes L=R/F𝐿𝑅𝐹L=R/F rounds, then we translate P1 to a series of P2 for f=1,2,…,F𝑓12…𝐹f=1,2,...,F.

P2:minx​(r),b​(r)⁡cf≜1L​∑r=f​L(f+1)​L−1y0​(x​(r),b​(r)):P2≜subscript𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟subscript𝑐𝑓1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑓𝐿𝑓1𝐿1subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟\displaystyle\textbf{P2}:~{}\min_{x(r),b(r)}{{c}_{f}}\triangleq\frac{1}{L}\sum\limits_{r=fL}^{(f+1)L-1}{{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r))} (16)
 s.t.​∑r=f​L(f+1)​L−1xk​(r)​Ek​(r)≤Hk/F,∀k s.t.superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑓𝐿𝑓1𝐿1subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝐹for-all𝑘\displaystyle\qquad{\quad\text{ s.t.}}~{}\sum\limits_{r=fL}^{(f+1)L-1}{{{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)}\leq{{H}_{k}}/F,\forall k (17)
Constraints​(13),(14),(15)Constraints131415\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\quad\text{Constraints}(13),(14),(15)

It can be found that P2 is still an offline problem, and we denote cf∗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑓c_{f}^{*} as the optimal value of (16) by L-round lookahead algorithm, which finds the optimal solution by foreseeing full offline knowledge over the frame in advance [8]. We assume throughout that the constraints are feasible for P2, such as there is no client is selected in any round. Therefor we use 1F​∑f=0F−1cf∗1𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑓0𝐹1superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑓\frac{1}{F}\sum_{f=0}^{F-1}{c_{f}^{*}} to approach the optimal value of P1.

III Online Optimization Algorithm and Convergence Analysis

In this section, we develop the Per-round Energy Drift Plus Cost algorithm, called PEDPC, to turn P2 to a series of online problems and develop the iterative algorithm to select clients and allocate bandwidth iteratively. Specifically we propose the Increasing Time-Maximum Client Selection algorithm to select clients, called ITMCS, and adopt the Barrier Method algorithm to allocate bandwidth for the selected clients at each round. Fig. 2 demonstrates the problem transform and algorithm framework.

III-A The PEDPC Algorithm

One major challenge of solving P2 is that constraint (17) couples long-term energy restrict which need to be decoupled into per-round term. For this, we apply the Lyapunov theory [11] and introduce a virtual queue Zk={Zk​(0),Zk​(1),⋯,Zk​(R−1)}subscript𝑍𝑘subscript𝑍𝑘0subscript𝑍𝑘1⋯subscript𝑍𝑘𝑅1{{Z}_{k}}=\{{{Z}_{k}}(0),{{Z}_{k}}(1),\cdots,{{Z}_{k}}(R-1)\} for client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Besides, we denote the queue backlog vector as Z​(r)={Z1​(r),Z2​(r),⋯,ZK​(r)}𝑍𝑟subscript𝑍1𝑟subscript𝑍2𝑟⋯subscript𝑍𝐾𝑟Z(r)=\{{{Z}_{1}}(r),{{Z}_{2}}(r),\cdots,{{Z}_{K}}(r)\} in round r𝑟r. Each queue is configured as follows:

Zk​(r+1)=max⁡[Zk​(r)+xk​(r)​Ek​(r)−Hk/R,0]subscript𝑍𝑘𝑟1subscript𝑍𝑘𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅0{{Z}_{k}}(r+1)=\max[{{Z}_{k}}(r)+{{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)-{{H}_{k}}/R,0] (18)

where Zk​(r)subscript𝑍𝑘𝑟{{Z}_{k}}(r) is the queue backlogs of client k𝑘k in round r𝑟r, and represents the difference between the energy consumption and budget of client k𝑘kover r𝑟r rounds. According to [11], the Lyapunov function Y​(Z​(r))𝑌𝑍𝑟Y(Z(r)) can be given by:

Y​(Z​(r))=12​∑k=1KZk​(r)2𝑌𝑍𝑟12superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑍𝑘superscript𝑟2Y(Z(r))=\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{{{Z}_{k}}{{(r)}^{2}}} (19)

This represents a scalar measure of queue congestion in the network. Besides, we denote the energy drift function as the change of Lyapunov function between two rounds: Y​(Z​(r+1))−Y​(Z​(r))𝑌𝑍𝑟1𝑌𝑍𝑟Y(Z(r+1))-Y(Z(r)), and an upper bound can be given by Lemma 1.

Y​(Z​(r+1))−Y​(Z​(r))𝑌𝑍𝑟1𝑌𝑍𝑟\displaystyle Y(Z(r+1))-Y(Z(r)) (20)

Now we formulate P3: in order to decoupled the constraint (17), we construct the objective of P3 by adding the upper bound of energy drift function to the per-round objective of P2 since the fact that Y​(Z​(r+1))−Y​(Z​(r))𝑌𝑍𝑟1𝑌𝑍𝑟Y(Z(r+1))-Y(Z(r)) being “small” for each round r≤R𝑟𝑅r\leq R implies the energy deficit of all clients being “small”. Thus P3 can be given by:

P3:minx​(r),b​(r)​∑k=1KZk​(r)​(xk​(r)​Ek​(r)−Hk/R):P3subscript𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑍𝑘𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅\displaystyle\textbf{P3}:~{}\min_{x(r),b(r)}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{{{Z}_{k}}(r)}({{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)-{{H}_{k}}/R)
+V​y0​(x​(r),b​(r))+D𝑉subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟𝐷\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad+V{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r))+D (21)
 s.t.​Constraints​(13),(14),(15) s.t.Constraints131415\displaystyle\qquad{\quad\text{ s.t.}}~{}\text{Constraints}(13),(14),(15)

where D𝐷D is a constant which can be omitted in optimizing. V>0𝑉0V>0 is a control parameter: when V𝑉V is close to zero, reducing energy consumption is more important, otherwise, reducing the cost function y0​(x​(r),b​(r))subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r)) is more crucial.

According to the above, we develop the PEDPC algorithm to solve P2 in an online way.

PEDPC algorithm decouple P2 to a series of per-round problem, in each round, only requires the current energy deficit and channel state to finish selecting clients and allocating bandwidth without foreseeing any future information. After each frame, we update the value of to dynamically adjust the key factors of P3, and more detailed impact of will be discussed in simulation results.

III-B The Iterative Algorithm

By considering the second term ∑k=1KZk​(r)​(xk​(r)​Ek​(r)−Hk/(R))superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑍𝑘𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅\sum_{k=1}^{K}{{{Z}_{k}}(r)}({{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)-{{H}_{k}}/(R))of (21), we can found that if one client is selected often, its energy queue backlog Zksubscript𝑍𝑘{{Z}_{k}} will be large which incurs that to reduce the energy deficit is more significant. Besides, if one client’s energy consumption exceeds the budget, then select this client less to decrease energy consumption. Plugging (5), (7), (8), (9) into (21) yields:

𝐏𝟑.𝐞𝐪:minx​(r),b​(r)[xk(r)(Tkcmp(r)+Skbk​(r)​Gk​(r))]\displaystyle\mathbf{P3.eq}:~{}\min_{x(r),b(r)}\left[{{x}_{k}}(r)\left(T_{k}^{\text{cmp}}(r)+\frac{{{S}_{k}}}{{{b}_{k}}(r){{G}_{k}}(r)}\right)\right]
−V​∑k=1Klog⁡(1+vk​xk​(r))𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑣𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad-V\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\log\left(1+{{v}_{k}}{{x}_{k}}(r)\right)}
+V​y0​(x​(r),b​(r))+D𝑉subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟𝐷\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad+V{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r))+D (22)
 s.t.​Constraints​(13),(14),(15) s.t.Constraints131415\displaystyle\qquad{\quad\text{ s.t.}}~{}\text{Constraints}(13),(14),(15)

where Notice that P3.eq is a mixed-integer problem and there is almost no algorithm to get the optimal solution in polynomial time. So we develop Iterative algorithm with low complexity in algorithm 2 to solve P3.eq.

Iterative algorithm contains two steps at each iteration: To solve P3.eq, we first fix one variable b​(r)𝑏𝑟b(r) and optimize x​(r)𝑥𝑟x(r) which is a 0-1 integer problem given in P4. Then we optimize b​(r)𝑏𝑟b(r) with fixed updated x​(r)𝑥𝑟x(r), which is a convex problem given in P5, The advantage of Iterative algorithm is that the objective value of P3.eq is non-increasing in each step and it always converges to a local optimal solution since the objective value is lower bounded by zero when we choose no client in round r𝑟r.

IV Algorithm Convergence and Complexity Analysis

In this section, we analyze the convergence and time complexity of our proposed algorithms.

IV-A Convergence Analysis

Assumption 1: For ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, ykmin≤xk​(r)​Ek​(r)−Hk/R≤ykmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}^{\min}\leq{{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)-{{H}_{k}}/R\leq y_{k}^{\max} where ykminsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}^{\min} and ykmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}^{\max} are constants and L>0𝐿0L>0, F>0𝐹0F>0. Assume the initial queue backlog vector Z​(0)𝑍0Z(0) is finite.

Definition 1: A discrete time queue Q​(t)𝑄𝑡Q(t) is mean rate stable if:

limr→∞​𝔼​{|Q​(t)|}t=0→𝑟𝔼𝑄𝑡𝑡0\underset{r\to\infty}{\mathop{\lim}}\,\frac{\mathbb{E}\{|Q(t)|\}}{t}=0 (26)

Proof : see appendix C.

Theorem 2: If the PEDPC algorithm is implemented every round, compared with L-round lookahead algorithm, the following inequality holds:

1R​∑r=0F​L−1y0​(x​(r),b​(r))≤1F​∑f=0F−1cf∗+D​LV+Y​(Z​(0))V​R1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟0𝐹𝐿1subscript𝑦0𝑥𝑟𝑏𝑟1𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑓0𝐹1superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑓𝐷𝐿𝑉𝑌𝑍0𝑉𝑅\frac{1}{R}\sum\limits_{r=0}^{FL-1}{{{y}_{0}}(x(r),b(r))}\leq\frac{1}{F}\sum\limits_{f=0}^{F-1}{c_{f}^{*}}+\frac{DL}{V}+\frac{Y(Z(0))}{VR} (28)

Theorem 2 implies that the difference between objective value by PEDPC algorithm and the optimal value is upper bounded by D​LV+Y​(Z​(0))V​R𝐷𝐿𝑉𝑌𝑍0𝑉𝑅\frac{DL}{V}+\frac{Y(Z(0))}{VR}. Thus we have that the objective of P1 is within O​(1/V)𝑂1𝑉O(1/V) of the optimal value. Now we compare the energy consumption of drift-plus-penalty algorithm with the L-round lookahead algorithm, and the following theorem holds:

Theorem 3: If the PEDPC algorithm is implemented every round, the virtual queue Z​(r)𝑍𝑟Z(r) is mean rate stable and the total energy consumption of client k𝑘k is upper bounded byHk+2​D​R​L+2​V​L​∑f=0F−1(cf∗−y0min)subscript𝐻𝑘2𝐷𝑅𝐿2𝑉𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑓0𝐹1superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑦0{{H}_{k}}+\sqrt{2DRL+2VL\sum_{f=0}^{F-1}{(c_{f}^{*}}-y_{0}^{\min})}.

Proof : see appendix E.

According to Theorem 2 and Theorem 3, we can found that the PEDPC algorithm can achieve [O​(1/V),O​(V)]𝑂1𝑉𝑂𝑉[O(1/V),O(\sqrt{V})] tradeoff between cost and energy consumption in our system model.

IV-B Complexity Analysis

To solve the origin problem P1 by using Algorithm 1, the major complexity depends on solving P5. According to [12], the time complexity of the barrier method is O​(⌈log⁡(2​m/(εb​r​α(0)))log⁡μ⌉)𝑂2𝑚subscript𝜀𝑏𝑟superscript𝛼0𝜇O\left(\left\lceil\frac{\log\left(2m/({{\varepsilon}_{br}}{{\alpha}^{(0)}})\right)}{\log\mu}\right\rceil\right). The complexity of Algorithm 2 is O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m), hence the time complexity of solving our proposed problem is O​(R​I​m​⌈log⁡(2​m/(εb​r​α(0)))log⁡μ⌉)𝑂𝑅𝐼𝑚2𝑚subscript𝜀𝑏𝑟superscript𝛼0𝜇O\left(RIm\left\lceil\frac{\log\left(2m/({{\varepsilon}_{br}}{{\alpha}^{(0)}})\right)}{\log\mu}\right\rceil\right). We can found that the complexity grows linearly with the product of the number of clients and FL iterative rounds.

V Simulation Results

V-A Experiment Settings

In our simulation, we consider the hand-written digit classification task on MNIST dataset [13]. For MNIST dataset, we apply a multi-layer perceptron which has two hidden layers with 10 hidden nodes each, and the number of parameters is 7960 (model parameter size Sk=0.24​M​b​i​t​ssubscript𝑆𝑘0.24𝑀𝑏𝑖𝑡𝑠{{S}_{k}}=0.24Mbits in 32-bit float). Besides, we consider two data distribution cases: 1) IID case, where the data of training set is shuffled and uniformly distributed over all clients. 2) NON-IID case, where the data size of each client is uniformly distributed in [1.2, 2.4, 3.6, 4.8, 6] Mbits. In addition, we sort the training data by the labels and divide them into 300 groups, every client choose 1-5 groups according to its own data size and at most contains five digits. FedAvg [3] is used as the learning algorithm in FL. The parameter settings are shown in TABLE I.

Furthermore, to verify the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm we consider the following four benchmark algorithms:

Select all: All clients are selected in each round, and the bandwidth is allocated equally.

Select randomly: For a given probabilityP​r𝑃𝑟Pr, randomly select P​r∗n𝑃𝑟𝑛Pr*n clients in each round, and the bandwidth is allocated equally for the selected clients, which is also called Randomly algorithm in our experiments.

Select greedily: Choose as many as clients within an energy limit, which is also called Greedily algorithm in our experiments. In each round, select clients by solving:

 s.t.​ ​xk​(r)​Ek​(r)≤Hk/R,∀k,∀r s.t. subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅for-all𝑘for-all𝑟\displaystyle\qquad{\quad\text{ s.t.}}~{}\text{ }{{x}_{k}}(r){{E}_{k}}(r)\leq{{H}_{k}}/R,\forall k,\forall r (30)
Constraints​(13),(14),(15)Constraints131415\displaystyle\qquad{\qquad\quad}\text{Constraints}(13),(14),(15)

This problem can be solved by:1) according to Ek​(r)=Hk/Rsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑟subscript𝐻𝑘𝑅{{E}_{k}}(r)={{H}_{k}}/R calculate the bandwidth vector of all clients bg​(r)={b1g​(r),b2g​(r),…,bkg​(r)}superscript𝑏𝑔𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑔𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑏2𝑔𝑟…superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑔𝑟{{b}^{g}}(r)=\{b_{1}^{g}(r),b_{2}^{g}(r),...,b_{k}^{g}(r)\}; 2) set Sg=∅superscript𝑆𝑔{{S}^{g}}=\varnothing and big​(r)=bminsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑔𝑟subscript𝑏b_{i}^{g}(r)={{b}_{\min}}, for i∈{i|big≤bmin}𝑖conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑔subscript𝑏i\in\{i|b_{i}^{g}\leq{{b}_{\min}}\}; 3) rank bg​(r)superscript𝑏𝑔𝑟{{b}^{g}}(r) in the ascending order and add client one by one to Sgsuperscript𝑆𝑔{{S}^{g}} until the total bandwidth of all clients of Sgsuperscript𝑆𝑔{{S}^{g}}exceeds B𝐵B. 4) set xk​(r)=1subscript𝑥𝑘𝑟1{{x}_{k}}(r)=1 for k∈Sg𝑘superscript𝑆𝑔k\in{{S}^{g}}, and other clients are not selected.

the solution is similar as the Greedily algorithm.

V-B Impact of V𝑉V

In PEDPC, V𝑉V is a vital parameter to control the key optimizing factors of P3. In this section, we simulate the impact of V𝑉V on the average number of clients, latency and energy overflow in FL. Specially energy overflow equals the energy consumption minus the energy budget).

Fig. 2 shows the trend of average number of selected clients, time latency and energy overflow as V𝑉V growing. As we can see, a large V𝑉V emphasizes more on the cost function resulting in more clients selected and slow growth time latency. Oppositely, a small V𝑉V emphasizes more on the energy consumption, which incurs a small overflow on the energy budget.

V-C Performance Comparison

To verify the performance of PEDPC, we experiment under IID and NON-IID data distributions.

Fig. 3 shows the energy overflow, time latency and accuracy of PEDPC and benchmarks in IID case. For comparison purpose, we set the average client number of above algorithms to be 40 other than Select all. Compared with Greedily, PEDPC saves about 5.5∼6.5similar-to5.56.55.5\sim 6.5 times energy and latency, meanwhile achieves a higher accuracy. For selecting more clients, Greedily assigns each client the minimum bandwidth meeting the energy constraint which leads to a huge consumption of latency. Compared with Randomly, we can found that PEDPC saves about 5.8∼8.0similar-to5.88.05.8\sim 8.0 times energy and time latency while achieving a higher accuracy. This is because Randomly distributes bandwidth evenly for all selected clients, and takes no account of the consumption of energy and time, which incurs the energy and latency a rise. Even though FedCS saves three times latency of our proposed algorithm, it uses 26.6 times energy of ours. This is because FedCS takes no account of energy consumption. Because Select all algorithm picks up all clients, its energy consumption and time latency are much larger than ours.

Fig. 4 shows the energy overflow, time latency and accuracy of PEDPC and benchmarks in NON-IID case. For comparison purpose, we set the average number of clients 90 other than Select all. Because of the similar number of selected clients, the accuracy of all algorithms does not differ by more than 3 percents. Compared with Greedily and Randomly, the time latency of PEDPC achieves 33%percent3333\% of above two algorithms under a similar energy consumption. This is because the bandwidth allocation of these two algorithms without regarding to the latency. As the number of clients increasing, the advantage of FedCS in saving time gradually diminishes, and the energy consumption is 4.5 times of ours since the bandwidth allocation policy omits the energy consumption. Select all takes much more energy and time latency than ours.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we propose a joint optimization algorithm PEDPC with considering client selection and bandwidth allocation for wireless federated leaning. In PEDPC, We exploit the Lyapunov-based energy deficit queue to solve the optimization problem with ITMCS algorithm from an online optimization perspective. Then we prove that PEDPC can achieve an [O​(1/V),(V)]𝑂1𝑉𝑉[O(1/V),(\sqrt{V})] cost-energy tradeoff. The extensive simulations show PEDPC achieves a better performance comparing with Sellect all, Randomly, Greedily, and FedCS in terms of energy consumption, time latency and FL accuracy.
